title: 103_hr63
content:
The "Spring Mountains National Recreation Area Act" defines National Forest lands, the Recreation Area, and the Secretary of Agriculture. The Act establishes the Spring Mountains National Recreation Area for recreational purposes. The Act aims to preserve various values in the Spring Mountains of Nevada, ensure conservation and management of natural resources, and provide recreation opportunities for present and future generations. Established the Spring Mountains National Recreation Area in Nevada, covering approximately 316,000 acres of federally owned lands in the Toiyabe National Forest. A map of the Recreation Area will be filed for public inspection, ensuring conservation and management of natural resources. In case of discrepancies between acreage and map, the map controls boundaries of the Recreation Area. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT. The Secretary manages the Recreation Area to conserve values, fish and wildlife, watersheds, and provide outdoor recreation benefits. This includes wilderness areas designated by Congress. The Secretary manages the Recreation Area to conserve values, fish and wildlife, watersheds, and provide outdoor recreation benefits, including designated wilderness areas. The Secretary permits hunting, trapping, fishing, and habitat management within the Recreation Area, with exceptions for public safety and administration. Grazing of livestock on Federal lands may continue under reasonable regulations. The Secretary may implement reasonable regulations, policies, and practices to protect the land and resources in the Recreation Area from fire, insects, or disease infestation. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary must develop a general management plan for the Recreation Area within 3 fiscal years of this Act's enactment. The plan will be an amendment to the Toiyabe National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan, reflecting the Recreation Area's establishment and aligning with this Act's provisions. The public will have access to the recreation area-related portions of the forest plan in a separate document. The management plan for the Recreation Area must include public participation, interpretation programs, facility proposals, and resource management focusing on archaeological preservation and enforcement of relevant acts. The management plan for the Recreation Area must include public participation, interpretation programs, facility proposals, and resource management focusing on archaeological preservation. Additionally, plans for wildlife and fish resource management, recreation management, wild horse and burro herd management, and an inventory of non-National Forest lands within the area for possible future acquisitions are required. The management plan for the Recreation Area must include public participation, interpretation programs, facility proposals, and resource management focusing on archaeological preservation. Plans for wildlife and fish resource management, recreation management, wild horse and burro herd management, and an inventory of non-National Forest lands for possible future acquisitions are required. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation and the Nevada State Department of Conservation and Natural Resources for the management of natural and cultural resources. The general management plan will incorporate recommendations from the Bureau of Land Management regarding the suitability for wilderness preservation of specific areas within the Recreation Area. The Secretary, through the Chief of the Forest Service, will manage lands within wilderness study areas to maintain their potential for inclusion in the National Wilderness Preservation System, as per the Status Map dated March 1990. SEC. 7. ACQUISITION OF LANDS. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the Recreation Area by donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency. Lands owned by the State of Nevada may only be acquired by donation or exchange. Acquired lands shall be managed according to National Forest System laws and regulations. The Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 allows for the acquisition of lands and interests within the National Forest System for conservation purposes. Money from the Fund can be used for this purpose. SEC. 8. WITHDRAWAL. Federal lands within the Recreation Area are withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws, except for specified lands. 

SEC. 9. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with other agencies and entities to manage natural and cultural resources in southern Nevada efficiently. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
